persons.name: JamesHall
persons.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

persons.name: Barnaba Niccolò Maria LuigiChiaramonti
persons.description: Pope Pius VII, 1800-1823, held prisioner by Buonparte, 1809-1813. In February 1814 Davy and his party stayed in the same inn that Pius had used the week before on his way back to Rome.

places.name: Albulae Aquae
places.description: White Waters'; a group of springs to the west of Tivolo, Italy, and location of an ancient Roman settlement.

places.name: Paestum
places.description: Paestum was an ancient Greek city on the coast of southern Italy.

places.name: Carniola
places.description: The Alpine region whose capital was Laybach (now Ljubljana). In 1827, Carniola was a Duchy within the Austrian Kingdom of Illyria.

places.name: Traun
places.description: Traunfall in Desselbrunn, Upper Austria. Memoirs contains a poem Davy wrote about them, also in notebook 14E.

places.name: Mount Etna
places.description: Mount Etna, or simply Etna, is an active stratovolcano on the east coast of Sicily, Italy.

persons.name: JohnMilton
persons.description: Milton was a poet and polemicist. He wrote the epic poem Paradise Lost.

persons.name: JosephineDetela
persons.description: The daughter of the landlord of the Laybach (Ljubljana) inn at which Davy stayed in 1827 and 1828. Davy nicknamed her 'Pepina'. In Consolations in Travel (1830) he portrayed her in idealised terms as his nurturing nurse.

persons.name: Ambrosio
persons.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

persons.name: JohnArmstrong
persons.description: Scottish physician and poet.

places.name: Naples

persons.name: Socrates
persons.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

persons.name: Thomas Stamford BingleyRaffles
persons.description: British colonial official who served as the governor of the Dutch East Indies between 1811 and 1816 and lieutenant-governor of Bencoolen between 1818 and 1824. Because he had opposed (or restricted) the slave trade in his colonial administration, he was refused burial inside a parish church, and his gravesite was lost until 1914.

places.name: Ravenna
places.description: Ravenna is a city in the north-east of Italy, near the coast of the Adriatic Sea.

places.name: Bad Aussee
places.description: In Styria (Bad Aussee). Bad Aussee is a town in the Austrian state of Styria located at the confluence of the three sources of the Traun River.

places.name: France
places.description: France, officially the French Republic, is a country located primarily in Western Europe.

persons.name: WilliamRichardson
persons.description: Irish cleric, geologist, agriculturist and pamphleteer. Davy stayed with him when investigating the Giant's Causeway in Country Antrim.

persons.name: WilliamBissett
persons.description: Younger brother of Sophia Brownrigg; Bishop of Raphoe

persons.name: ShuteBarrington
persons.description: Bishop of Durham, 1791 until death. An early Proprietor of the Royal Institution who hosted Davy when he was in the North-East working on his safety lamp.

persons.name: SophiaBrownrigg
persons.description: Wife of Sir Robert Brownrigg (q.v.), Governor of Ceylon.

persons.name: ThomasBernard
persons.description: Philantropist and a founding member of the Royal Institution serving as an early Treasurer. Later influential in running the institution, especially its lecture programme.

places.name: Cornwall
places.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

places.name: Land's End
places.description: Land's End is a headland on the west coast of Cornwall. It is the most westerly point of mainland England. The underlying rock at Land's End is granite.
